text:
- I think the key to life
is knowing who you're not.
That is so important
because you might wake up 10 years later
and be like, I am not a farmer.
But here I am with a whole farm.
(upbeat music)
(objects whirring)
I'm Atsuko Okatsuka and I'm a comedian.

In what aspect of your life
do you feel not good enough?

When is the first time you
remember feeling that way?
(object rolling)
I think I'm kind of finding

that I'm more of a
perfectionist than I thought.
I used to be like, oh, I'm so chill.
You know, and I am.

But for me it's always
about, like, knowing
that there's always improvement.
I watch back every show that I do.
I'm looking at my movements.

I'm seeing if I have started
doing the joke slower

or faster, or if I'm even
enunciating a word weirder.

I'm always thinking there's
room for improvement,
especially with craft,

but then feeling not good
enough as a person in general.
The first time I felt that, I think I felt
that multiple times in my life.

I had a unique upbringing where
I wasn't just an immigrant.
Like, my mom has schizophrenia,

and then my dad who
had full custody of me,

my grandma lied to. My
grandma kidnapped me from him.
There were other things that made me feel
like I was a bit of a freak.

And that kind of just repeats
itself throughout life,
I feel like, in different ways.

For example, like, when I
first came to the States
and I was still learning English,

I remember I was playing
with, like, these two girls
and there was another person that came
and, like, wanted to play with us.
And I said, "yeah, you can play with we."
And then the two girls started laughing

'cause they were like,
haha, you mean "us".

You know, I remember kind of
shutting down a little bit
because I was like, oh, I don't even know
what the correct thing is.
I just know I'm wrong, you know?

And I don't know how to fix
it and that's kind of scary,
feeling stuck. Thinking back,

maybe that's where, you know,
wanting things to be perfect,

the way I present myself to
people, even as a performer.
I think maybe that does come from that,

where it's like, I don't
wanna feel that way again.

I think about this all the
time with immigrant comedians.
I'm not funny in Japanese or Mandarin.

I got funny in the language
that I struggle that the most

and that I desperately
wanted to try to connect
with people the most.
Yeah, I think about it all the time, yeah.
(object whirring)
Who are you still trying to please?
I am a big people pleaser.
I think a lot of comedians are,
but I'm a huge people pleaser.

My mom was really
unpredictable growing up,

so I was always like,
does this make you happy?

Should I go away? Does
that make you happy?
Do you want me to listen to you talk?
Does that make you happy? Should I talk?
Does that make you happy?
Because of that, I don't ever want people

to feel disappointed,
so I always say "yes".

And then, you know, when
I can't deliver, right?
It's actually a bigger disappointment

to the people than if I just
said "no" in the first place.
And so that's something I've had to learn.

You can take time. Don't answer
anything based on emotion.

Feel the emotion--oh, I
feel bad if I say "no".

Oh, I feel guilty. I feel
guilty if I say "no".
Let that feeling pass and then answer,

'cause then you've already
played out the guilty part.

You've already felt the
guilty part in your body.

And then after you took a few
deep breaths, I don't know,

took a little walk, it'll
be easier to say "no"
or respond after that.
(object whirring)

Where has pain served
a purpose in your life?

My dad and I were separated
for many years, you know,
after my grandma brought me to the States

kind of abruptly without
telling us. We reconnected,

but then we never really talked
about what happened, right?
How it made us feel.
How were you feeling at the time?

What were you going through,
what was I going through?
We never talked about it.

And then Ira Glass from
This American Life was like,

do you want to do an episode
about this possible kidnapping
that your grandma did on you?
And I was like, yeah, because for me,

and it's a sick thing, but
sometimes it takes a project

for you to go, okay, I'm
gonna face that pain.

I'm gonna face that fear and
I'll do it for the public.
Confronting it was painful
and it was really, really sad, you know,

because there were
chunks of stories missing
that I just had filled it in with my head.

- [Speaker] Right now, I'm
almost about to cry a little.

So basically your grandma
told me in a letter
that you are really missing me.

And that's when I think I
knew you were in America.

- It was very sad to hear
how devastated my dad was,
how lonely he was, how much he missed me,
how he tried to see me again,
things like this that I didn't know.

It was good because it also,
I think, healed a hole.
It's sad, but it's good.
And we can continue to love each other

and really have a great
relationship from now on.
(gentle music)

What need inside yourself
have you been neglecting?
When did you start neglecting it and why?

You know, I constantly
struggle with, like, trying

to figure out if it's a need
that I truly need for myself,

or if it's a need I see other
people needing for them.
So I try to copy them.
You hike? Oh, maybe I'm a hiker, too.
Oh, you see a therapist?
Maybe I should see one.

It still goes back to
trying to fit in, I think,
and feeling like belonging.

Strangely, I started feeling
like I finally belong,
or I have a community
when I became more known as a comedian.

I started sharing my feelings
more with the people.
My family raised me on mind tricks.
These mind tricks, you know?

Yeah, and if you're an
immigrant or children

of immigrants, you
might be able to relate.
I had been doing comedy already,

but like, I never even talked
about my mom's schizophrenia.

I didn't know how, I
truly wish schizophrenia
had a more approachable name.
You know, something like Splash Mountain.
You do all these things.

You tiptoe around, you're
afraid to be the thing
that you actually are
because if you're not accepted
for who you actually are, then shoot.
It's like, that's all you had.
So sometimes you arrive at that last.
(audience cheering)

It's weird that I had to
open myself up so much.
I found comedy. I became an entertainer
to be able to finally feel like I belong.
